text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Removed reference in IRM 4.71.8.1.1 to IRM 1.2.10 and IRM 1.2.13 since the manual sections were obsoleted.

Revisions were made throughout the IRM to incorporate the October 2, 2018 memorandum from the Acting Director, Government Entities/Shared Services titled, Revised Process for Surveying a Case When Using Certain Non-examination Disposal Codes.
Updated IRM 4.71.8.5.1 to provide additional guidance Completing Form 5599 when Claim Is Allowed in Full Without Taxpayer Contact.
Updated IRM 4.71.8.6.1 to remove the requirement to complete a F5438 when a Claim is Allowed Full and Taxpayer contact has been made.
Updated IRM 4.71.8.6.2 (3) to provide information regarding the ﬁelds on the RCCMS compliance record that differed from IRM 4.71.8.5.2.
Updated IRM 4.71.8.6(3)(8)a to provide the entries of the required Form 5599 ﬁelds that differed from
Updated IRM 4.71.8.6(3)(8)b to provide information regarding the ﬁelds on the RCCMS compliance record that differed from IRM 4.71.8.5.2.
Updated IRM 4.71.8.6.3(10)c to require Letter 2841-A for a closing letter when the taxpayer signs and returns Forms 2297 and 3363 and there is no balance due on the applicable tax module.
IRM 4.71.8.7 to add a note regarding the term “if ever qualiﬁed”.
This supersedes IRM 4.71.8 dated December 6, 2018.
Tax Exempt and Government Entities Employee Plans
Acting Director, Employee Plans Tax Exempt and Government Entities
Table of Contents
) Purpose: IRM
, Employee Plans Examination of Returns, EP Claims, provides the basic examination procedures to help Employee Plans (EP) Scope and agents and their managers process claim cases. (
) Audience: This IRM provides procedures for agents, managers, and support staff in EP Exam. (
) Program Owner: Director, EP Examinations. (
) Program Authority: EP Examinations derives its authority to conduct exami- nations, resolve issues and determine tax liability from Title
, Internal Revenue Code, Subtitle F – Procedure and Administration, which includes is not limited to: a. IRC
- Examination of books and witnesses, which falls under Chapter
- Discovery of Liability and Enforcement of Title. It gives agents the authority to:

Audit any books, papers, records or other data necessary to complete an audit. Take testimony under oath to secure additional information needed. Issue summons for information necessary to complete an audit. Ask about any offense connected to the administering or enforcing of the Revenue laws.
Ask about any offense connected to the administering or enforcing of the Internal Revenue laws. b. IRC
- Assessment authority, which falls under Chapter
- ment, gives EP Examinations authority to r (
) This IRM section is written by EP Mandatory Review. For questions, tion or suggestions, contact the manager of EP Mandatory Review. (
) EP Examinations determines if a retirement plan is qualiﬁed under IRC
and the underlying regulations, and therefore, exempt from tax under IRC (
) EP Examinations audit program’s primary objective is regulatory, continued qualiﬁcation of employee beneﬁt plans (Policy Statement

). Examinations selects and examines returns to: a. Promote the highest degree of voluntary compliance with the tax laws plan qualiﬁcation. b. Determine qualiﬁed plans’ extent of compliance and the causes of non- compliance with the tax laws. c. Determine whether such plans meet the applicable qualiﬁcation ments in operation. (
) Under Policy Statement

, EP agents and managers are: a. Given broad authority to consider and weigh conﬂicting information, and opinions. b. To use professional judgement according to examination standards to make ﬁndings of fact and apply the IRS’s position on issues of law to determine the correct tax liability. c. To exercise this authority to get the greatest number of tax agreements without sacriﬁcing the quality or integrity of those tions and to dispose of tax differences at the lowest level. (
) All examinations are done per Policy Statement
, Fairness and in Enforcement Selection.
IRC 6201 - Assessment authority, which falls under Chapter 63 - ment, gives EP Examinations authority to r
This IRM section is written by EP Mandatory Review. For questions, tion or suggestions, contact the manager of EP Mandatory Review.
EP Examinations determines if a retirement plan is qualiﬁed under IRC 401 and the underlying regulations, and therefore, exempt from tax under IRC 501.
Promote the highest degree of voluntary compliance with the tax laws on plan qualiﬁcation. Determine qualiﬁed plans’ extent of compliance and the causes of non
compliance with the tax laws. Determine whether such plans meet the applicable qualiﬁcation require
ments in operation.

a. Given broad authority to consider and weigh conﬂicting information, and opinions. b. To use professional judgement according to examination standards to make ﬁndings of fact and apply the IRS’s position on issues of law to determine the correct tax liability. c. To exercise this authority to get the greatest number of tax agreements without sacriﬁcing the quality or integrity of those tions and to dispose of tax differences at the lowest level.
Employee Plans Examination of Returns

) EP Examinations established two review groups to make sure agents conduct examinations per technical, procedural and administrative requirements: a. Mandatory Review, see IRM
, Employee Plans Examination of Returns, EP Mandatory Review. b. Special Review, see IRM
, Special Review (SR) and Tax Exempt Quality Measurement System (TEQMS) Procedures. (
) Tax Exempt Quality Measurement System (TEQMS) is the quality control system TE/GE uses to oversee the entire examination program. For more in- formation on TEQMS, see IRM
, Special Review (SR) and Tax Exempt Quality Measurement System (TEQMS) Procedures. (
) All examinations are done per the Taxpayer Bill of Rights as listed in IRC
Note: Find additional information at: Taxpayer Bill of Rights

The IRS is fully committed to protecting the privacy rights of taxpayers and employees. Privacy laws are included in the IRC, the Privacy Act of 1974, the Freedom of Information Act, and IRS policies and practices.
Employee Plans Examination of Returns
Important contact information for individuals and business units referenced in this IRM are found in IRM 4.71.1 Exhibit 13 at IRM 4.71 - Employee Plans Ex- amination Exhibits.
This IRM provides guidance for EP agents to process claim cases and gives- miscellaneous procedures for:
Note: See IRM 4.71.8 Exhibit 1 at IRM 4.71 - Employee Plans Examina- tion Exhibits for an example of a completed Form 843.
Note: Taxpayers can use his form to request a refund and to abate interest and penalties.
In general, work a claim as a limited scope correspondence examinations.

a. Complete workpapers for the scope of the claim case. At a minimum, include in your workpapers: a brief description of how the claim came about, what the issue was, what referrals were made (if any), who contacted, what IDRS research you did, and what conclusions you reached. b. Assemble the case ﬁle per IRM

, Special Case File Instructions for Claims. c. Use a separate case ﬁle folder for each year and return type to which claim applies. Research IDRS to ensure that all claim years are properly established on AIMS and RCCMS. a. Secure an AMDISA print to ensure that all years for which a claim has been ﬁled are properly established on AIMS. b. If the claim isn’t established, follow the procedures in IRM
, Establishing Claims on AIMS and RCCMS. Report your time working the claim on We
TS and list: • Each year to which a claim applies • The applicable activity code for the return • Project code

Complete workpapers for the scope of the claim case. At a minimum, include in your workpapers: a brief description of how the claim came about, what the issue was, what referrals were made (if any), who you contacted, what IDRS research you did, and what conclusions you reached. Assemble the case ﬁle per IRM
, Special Case File Assembly Instructions for Claims. Use a separate case ﬁle folder for each year and return type to which claim applies.

) Although normally worked by Classiﬁcation, you may close an assigned case without contacting the taxpayer or POA if you determine that the Allowed in Full, issue is clearly allowable in full and the return doesn’t otherwise warrant Contact amination. These are referred to as “surveyed” claims. (
) Generally, when there’s no indication that the case was selected because the contents of the return, you can decide to “survey” the claim by the claim issue only.

Although normally worked by Classiﬁcation, you may close an assigned claim case without contacting the taxpayer or POA if you determine that the claim issue is clearly allowable in full and the return doesn’t otherwise warrant ex
amination. These are referred to as “surveyed” claims.
) The only claims that may not be “surveyed” are those that require Appeals consideration, or which, if allowed would produce overpayments or credits requiring Joint Committee Review. a. IRC

IRS is prohibited from any levy or court proceeding for the collection of the 100% tax under IRC 4971 or IRC 4975 pending the ﬁnal resolution of court proceedings on the ﬁrst tier tax under those Code sections if the taxpayer timely pays the ﬁrst tier tax and ﬁles a claim for refund (IRC 4961).

(b) Excise Tax. Note: Excise taxes imposed by IRC

are dependent on a plan that was ever qualiﬁed under IRC
(a) (or was determined by Secretary to have been qualiﬁed) under IRC
(a), or (
) satisﬁed (or determined by the Secretary to have satisﬁed) the requirements of IRC

(a). The term “if ever qualiﬁed” can take on many meanings on the facts and circumstances. Generally, any plan that has ever had a termination letter regardless of whether the plan later ceased to be a qualiﬁed plan because of a form or operational defect and whether or not determination letter is subsequently revoked meets the deﬁnition of “if qualiﬁed”. Other considerations are whether the employer ever took a deduction for contributions to a plan or made rollovers from the plan reference PLR
Accordingly, a claim ﬁled requesting an or refund of excise tax imposed by IRC
(a) and IRC
(a) is likely allowable. There is nothing in the Code that provides relief from the ﬁrst tax. If there is a question as to whether the plan was ever qualiﬁed, Area Counsel.
If you determine that the ﬁrst tier tax under IRC 4971 or IRC 4975 should be imposed, solicit a delinquent Form 5330 and request payment of the tax.

Generally, any plan that has ever had a de- termination letter regardless of whether the plan later ceased to be a qualiﬁed plan because of a form or operational defect and whether or not determination letter is subsequently revoked meets the deﬁnition of “if ever qualiﬁed”. Other considerations are whether the employer ever took a deduction for contributions to a plan or made rollovers from the plan reference PLR
Accordingly, a claim ﬁled requesting an abatement or refund of excise tax imposed by IRC
(a) and IRC
(a) is likely allowable. There is nothing in the Code that provides relief from the ﬁrst tier tax. If there is a question as to whether the plan was ever qualiﬁed, contact Area Counsel.

(12-17-2019) Abatement of Interest Due to IRS Delay or Error
Note: See IRM 20.2.7, Abatement and Suspension of Debit Interest, for additional information on this provision.
A “ministerial act” is a procedural act or mechanical act that doesn’t involve the exercise of judgment or discretion and occurs when IRS processes a taxpay
er’s case after we’ve completed all prerequisites to the act, such as conferences and reviews by supervisors.

IRS sends an audit selection letter to the taxpayer’s old address and it’s forwarded to the new address. In response to the appointment letter, the taxpayer notiﬁes the IRS of the new address and requests a transfer of the audit to an office closer to the new address. The group manager approves the transfer request. The IRS, in its discretion, may abate interest attributable to any unreasonable delay in transferring the case.
Employee Plans Examination of Returns

) A “managerial act” is an administrative act that occurs during IRS’s of a taxpayer’s case. It involves the temporary or permanent loss of records the exercise of judgment or discretion of IRS management. Example: Continuing with the example in IRM

), after the manager approves the transfer of the case, the clerk misplaces the case ﬁle. “misplacing of the ﬁle” is a managerial act. The IRS, at its discretion, may abate interest attributable to any unreasonable delay caused by ﬁle’s misplacement. (
) The IRS has the authority to abate the amount of interest that accrued the period in which the unreasonable error or delay in performing a or managerial act occurred (IRC

)). a. It applies only when an unreasonable error or delay occurred after the date the IRS contacts the taxpayer in writing for an audit deﬁciency or payment. b. Interest which already accrued from the return due date to when the ﬁrst contacts the taxpayer isn’t abated under this provision because taxpayer is aware of the tax liability reported on the ﬁled return as well the consequences (which are penalties and interest) if they don’t pay liability by the return due date. (
) The IRS has discretionary authority to allow claims for abatement of interest when all of the following conditions are met: a. The statutory period of limitations under IRC
on ﬁling a claim has not expired. b. The claim relates to interest on IRC
(a) taxes, such as income, estate, gift and excise taxes under Chapters
, and
Note: IRC

) does not allow abatement of interest on employ- ment tax deﬁciencies or payments. c. An unreasonable error or delay occurred in relation to the performance a ministerial or managerial act. d. Error or delay occurred after the taxpayer was contacted in writing respect to the examination, deﬁciency, or payment. e. No signiﬁcant aspect of the error or delay can be attributed to the taxpayer/representative. Note: An interest abatement claim under IRC
) not meeting all of the above criteria is automatically disallowed by law. (
) Taxpayers must request abatement of interest on Form

A “managerial act” is an administrative act that occurs during IRS’s processing of a taxpayer’s case. It involves the temporary or permanent loss of records or the exercise of judgment or discretion of IRS management.
Continuing with the example in IRM

), after the manager approves the transfer of the case, the clerk misplaces the case ﬁle. The “misplacing of the ﬁle” is a managerial act. The IRS, at its discretion, may abate interest attributable to any unreasonable delay caused by the ﬁle’s misplacement.

It applies only when an unreasonable error or delay occurred after the date the IRS contacts the taxpayer in writing for an audit deﬁciency or payment. Interest which already accrued from the return due date to when the ﬁrst contacts the taxpayer isn’t abated under this provision because the taxpayer is aware of the tax liability reported on the ﬁled return as well the consequences (which are penalties and interest) if they don’t pay liability by the return due date.

An unreasonable error or delay occurred in relation to the performance a ministerial or managerial act. Error or delay occurred after the taxpayer was contacted in writing with respect to the examination, deﬁciency, or payment. No signiﬁcant aspect of the error or delay can be attributed to the taxpayer/representative.
Note: An interest abatement claim under IRC 6404(e)(1) not meeting all of the above criteria is automatically disallowed by law.
